Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[build] set VSIX compression level to Normal" (#1932) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
While generating a VSIX, I noticed this in the build log:

    CreateVsixContainer:
      Creating VSIX Container...
      Creating the package with the following compression level. "NotCompressed".

Changing the `ZipPackageCompressionLevel` property to `Normal`, seems
to change the VSIX so it is properly compressed.

The file size goes from 584991368 bytes to 172998318 bytes.

It's worth doing this, just to make the download smaller in the OSS
repo. I need to do some further research and make sure the VSIX we are
shipping commercially is compressed.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Add Linux Mint to the fold" (#1955) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Add detection and preparation script for the Linux Mint distribution. Since Mint
is based on Ubuntu, this patch reorganizes things a little bit to reuse as much
of Ubuntu specific code as possible.

Events.RelatedBody: This test is failing rather consistently on many physical devices. See https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/issues/1534 for more info.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "UpdateAndroidResgen target is skipped on High Sierra after touching a resource file" (#1962) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Build project once.
2. Touch the layout file associated with the main activity of the project.
3. Build project again.

<!--
If you have a repro project, you may drag & drop the .zip/etc. onto the issue editor to attach it.
-->

### Expected Behavior
_UpdateAndroidResgen runs again after a minor change to a resource file. I'm seeing this in d15-8 on Windows 10 and macOS sierra.

Sierra - _UpdateAndroidResgen runs (passed):
http://xqa.blob.core.windows.net/gist/sierra-build-out-c16e2eb482834b98993ea94a141c8ed5.txt

### Actual Behavior
_UpdateAndroidResgen does not run after a minor change to a resource file. I'm only seeing this in High Sierra macOS environments, and it does seem to be a regression in d15-8.

High Sierra - _UpdateAndroidResgen is skipped (failed):
http://xqa.blob.core.windows.net/gist/log-53f53861e0864f38a84e2bb99262e833.txt

### Version Information
https://gist.github.com/pjcollins/700067943fa1b5778c2559aa9d208535
<!--
1. On macOS and within Visual Studio, select Visual Studio > About Visual Studio, then click the Show Details button, then click the Copy Information button.

2. Paste below this comment block.
-->

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[Xamarin.Android.Build.Tasks] we should set TargetFrameworkMonikerAssemblyAttributesPath" (#1961) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Context: https://github.com/Microsoft/msbuild/blob/b3f9eeab651c92bade6e4f64d11b59aa39e149cb/src/Tasks/Microsoft.Common.CurrentVersion.targets#L3305
Fixes: https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/issues/1960

While reviewing build logs, I have noticed something very odd if you
are building for `TargetFrameworkVersion=v6.0` and it gets switched to
a different one such as `TargetFrameworkVersion=v9.0`.

Here is the `GenerateTargetFrameworkMonikerAttribute` target from
`Microsoft.Common.CurrentVersion.targets`:

    WriteLinesToFile
        Parameters
            File = C:\Users\myuser\AppData\Local\Temp\MonoAndroid,Version=v6.0.AssemblyAttributes.cs
            Lines
                // <autogenerated />
                using System;
                using System.Reflection;
                [assembly: global::System.Runtime.Versioning.TargetFrameworkAttribute("MonoAndroid,Version=v9.0", FrameworkDisplayName = "Xamarin.Android v9.0 Support")]
            Overwrite = True

This was *very* odd, since it was writing a file named
`MonoAndroid,Version=v6.0.AssemblyAttributes.cs` but then writing
`[assembly: TargetFrameworkAttribute("MonoAndroid,Version=v9.0"]` into
it!

It appears we are seeing MSBuild's implementation of how
`[assembly: TargetFrameworkAttribute]` is added to a compiled assembly.
It writes to a temp file using the value from
`$(TargetFrameworkMonikerAssemblyAttributesPath)`. We are not setting
this property in `Xamarin.Android.Common.targets` after modifying the
value of `$(TargetFrameworkVersion)`.

What could this break?

Consider building multiple Xamarin.Android projects at the same time
with different `TargetFrameworkVersion` settings. The builds could
"step on each other" and write an inappropriate value into the temp
file!

In fact, this did actually occur, see an example from kzu here:
https://xamarinhq.slack.com/archives/C03CEGRUW/p1521475676000161

I added some additional code in `Xamarin.Android.Common.targets` to
set the `$(TargetFrameworkMonikerAssemblyAttributesPath)`
appropriately, and added a test to check for the problem.

I used the exact code from MSBuild, but we can do something else if
there is a better option:

https://github.com/Microsoft/msbuild/blob/b3f9eeab651c92bade6e4f64d11b59aa39e149cb/src/Tasks/Microsoft.Common.CurrentVersion.targets#L3305

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Incorrect $(TargetFrameworkMonikerAssemblyAttributesPath) behavior for MSBuild" (#1960) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
### Steps to Reproduce

While reviewing build logs, I have noticed something very odd if you
are building for `TargetFrameworkVersion=v6.0` and it gets switched to
a different one such as `TargetFrameworkVersion=v9.0`.

Here is the `GenerateTargetFrameworkMonikerAttribute` target from
`Microsoft.Common.CurrentVersion.targets`:

    WriteLinesToFile
        Parameters
            File = C:\Users\myuser\AppData\Local\Temp\MonoAndroid,Version=v6.0.AssemblyAttributes.cs
            Lines
                // <autogenerated />
                using System;
                using System.Reflection;
                [assembly: global::System.Runtime.Versioning.TargetFrameworkAttribute("MonoAndroid,Version=v9.0", FrameworkDisplayName = "Xamarin.Android v9.0 Support")]
            Overwrite = True

This was *very* odd, since it was writing a file named
`MonoAndroid,Version=v6.0.AssemblyAttributes.cs` but then writing
`[assembly: TargetFrameworkAttribute("MonoAndroid,Version=v9.0"]` into
it!

It appears we are seeing MSBuild's implementation of how
`[assembly: TargetFrameworkAttribute]` is added to a compiled assembly.
It writes to a temp file using the value from
`$(TargetFrameworkMonikerAssemblyAttributesPath)`. We are not setting
this property in `Xamarin.Android.Common.targets` after modifying the
value of `$(TargetFrameworkVersion)`.

### Expected Behavior

We shouldn't be writing incorrect `TargetFrameworkVersion` values into `$(Temp)\MonoAndroid,Version=*.AssemblyAttributes.cs` files.

### Actual Behavior

We are writing incorrect `TargetFrameworkVersion` values into `$(Temp)\MonoAndroid,Version=*.AssemblyAttributes.cs` files.

### Version Information

xamarin-android/master

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "iOS Button Released event not fired if Release occurs outside of Button's Layout" (#3310) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues -->

### Description
If you attach a Release event to a button in Xamarin Forms you'll notice that it won't get fired when running on iOS if you press the button, maintain your press and move your finger off of the button and then release.

### Steps to Reproduce

1.  In any XF project, add a button to your XAML with x:Name="Btn"
2. In code-behind, add:
Btn.Pressed += (sender, e) => { Btn.BackgroundColor = Color.LightSeaGreen; };
Btn.Released+= (sender, e) => { Btn.BackgroundColor = Color.Orange; };
3. Run on iOS simulator/device and press the button, maintain your press and move your finger off of the button and then release

### Expected Behavior
Released event would fire and change the button background color to Orange

### Actual Behavior
Released event does NOT fire and button background color remains LightSeaGreen that was set by the Pressed event.

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: latest
- Last known good version: n/a
- IDE: VS2017 Enterprise latest
- Platform Target Frameworks: <!-- All that apply -->
  - iOS: 11.4
- Nuget Packages: irrelevant
- Affected Devices: all

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Exception has been thrown by the target of an invocation when building with Xaml compilation enabled and setting Margin property on FlexLayout" (#3226) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues -->

### Description
Exception has been thrown by the target of an invocation when building with XamlC compilation enabled and setting Margin property on FlexLayout

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a Xamarin Forms project
2. Create a content page or view using XAML
3. Include a FlexLayout 
4. Set the Margin Property of that FlexLayout
5. Enable Xaml Compilation [assembly: XamlCompilation(XamlCompilationOptions.Compile)]

### Expected Behavior
Margin values are respected. 

### Actual Behavior
Error mentioned above 

### Basic Information
In the Visual Studio Xaml Preview the margin works fine. This also works fine when building without Xaml compilation.

- Version with issue:
- Last known good version: Unknown
- IDE: Visual Studio Mac
- Platform Target Frameworks: Xamarin.Forms 3.0 and 3.1

### Screenshots

<!-- If the issue is a visual issue, please include screenshots showing the problem if possible -->

### Reproduction Link

<!-- Please u
[FlexLayoutDemos.zip](https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/files/2168281/FlexLayoutDemos.zip)

pload or provide a link to a reproduction case -->

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NotImplementedException on WPF" (#3309) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
When executing Clear and Remove methods on ObservableCollection the exception is thrown: 'System.NotImplementedException' in Xamarin.Forms.Core.dll.
But if I cover it with try catch the result of the operation is correct.

Tested on
Xamarin latest 3.1 version
Platform WPF

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "PushModalAsync ignores NavigationPage on UWP" (#3305) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
On UWP, when a modal page is invoked like this:

``` c#
sourcePage.Navigation.PushModalAsync(new NavigationPage(modalRoot));
```

The resulting page does not use the navigation page. There is no title and the toolbar is not shown.

Xamarin.Forms 3.1.0.637273

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Button does not recalculate width on WPF" (#3308) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
On WPF, after a Button has been displayed, if you change its Text, its width doesn't change. This can cause the new text to be clipped.

Xamarin.Forms 3.1.0.637273

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Scroll bar overlaps content in WPF" (#3307) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
On WPF, a ScrollView always displays a vertical scroll bar if the content exceeds the ScrollView's height, regardless of `VerticalScrollBarVisibility`. The scroll bar overlaps the ScrollView's content. This overlap would be acceptable if the scroll bar were visible only temporarily, but it's permanent, which means the user never sees the content underneath.

Xamarin.Forms 3.1.0.637273

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "TimePicker with short time pattern shows verbose time" (#3306) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
On WPF, if you set `TimePicker.Format` to "t" ([short time](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/base-types/standard-date-and-time-format-strings#ShortTime)), and click in the TimePicker, text like `08:37:20.0544050` appears. Instead, the TimePicker should display a time like the output of `DateTime.Now.ToString("t")`, e.g. `8:47 AM`.

Xamarin.Forms 3.1.0.637273

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "PushModalAsync ignores NavigationPage on UWP" (#3305) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
On UWP, when a modal page is invoked like this:

``` c#
sourcePage.Navigation.PushModalAsync(new NavigationPage(modalRoot));
```

The resulting page does not use the navigation page. There is no title and the toolbar is not shown.

Xamarin.Forms 3.1.0.637273

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "My CPU sing me a song when when I worked on Xamarin.forms project." (#3304) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Opened issue "My CPU sing me a song when when I worked on Xamarin.forms project." (#3304) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
In my last night dream, I was working at Microsoft HQ, I was next cabin to Satya Nadella sir. This is for few days Like Google make new employee nooglers I see something there for me.

As we moving to AI, ML, Intel, and Microsoft sign a deal that Microsoft will use a single processor in the cloud, This is will save energy and make the world greener, For example, If you have a high-end processor and you are using Notepad, you may waste the power.

So I got a machine to work. I was so happy that my machine is processor-less (Processor is in Azure). I work happily and go home. Next day I come and start working on Xamarin Project.

We were having a security that if someone uses the too much processing and computing, computer play a song, like (TADA in XP), (Kalimba in Windows 7). We have a bunch of songs, AI, ML does found the pattern and play the song.

If you have used too much processor already and still consuming the next song will be from Skrillex's album.

I worked and the My computer was playing the song because I compiling my project every time (since I can't use edit and continue, I need to compile again for make changes).

Suddenly Satya Nadealla sir yell at me, "Hey Anirudha, What's going on, Look like you are consuming too much processing".

I told him "Sir, I am using Xamarin to make an app in C#".
Satya Nadella says, "OK, But why your PC was so silent yesterday".
I told him "I was using Flutter, All my code was done Hot reload, I didn't need to re-compile my code again for reflecting changes in flutter".
Satya Nadella sir say "Cool".

They meet with everyone working on Xamarin. I can see people's face & hear the voice. I hear people saying "This is going to be a major drawback with our whole mobile ecosystem, Everyone is using Phone in the pocket and not the heavy desktop so we need to take care of mobile thing first.".

The 1st person says "Let's focus on the problem and find solutions".
 2nd person say "I have a list of the problem which should be a big trouble when someone uses Xamarin", 

S N "Can you tell us the issues from your report".
2nd Person, "Yes, Sure, "

1. Using Xamarin consume a lot of CPU. Compare to Flutter, a lot more.
2. Hot reload is really missing in xamarin.forms (every post on internet say (even xamarin university) that if you want data entry app use Xamarin.forms otherwise use xamarin.android Hot reload is first missing feature here. The immediate window doesn't play well, everything is going very well troublesome sometimes. developers took days for fix things that is easily fixed in time in other platforms.

S N "How we are going to solve these issues ?"

2nd person "If hot reload is not going to be implemented soon, we will be left in the race of cross-platform". React native developer work without Android SDK or (Mac device to compile) and able to make a wonderful app. Flutter developer makes an app with a great performance and look, We should do something with Xamarin on Hot reload. 
S N "Ok, Put Hot reload in Backlog, Leave everything, this should be our first priority, Anyone has any more idea and issues".

Everyone has issues and ideas that I read  on xamarin.forums, One guys complain that some post  in xamarin.forms forums never get a single response when they goes out of scope. I was later invited to the same meet.

I was astonished when I see the screen, They point my Xamarin.forms post that I made in may 2018, it's have no response. I think in my mind, "Everyone read everything".

SN  "Ok, This issues is noted , What else we are going to do to make xamarin better."  
I answer "everything in xamarin is best , it's just not smooth, Like Flutter and React native, the developer doesn't get the speed.  Xamarin should do something to make the process more easier."

At the end of meeting I wake up in morning.  It was a good experience to meet people in my dream (no kidding), One thing that amazes me the most is if my dream come true, you all guys are going to have a computing power coming from Azure, and it's have security to alert the developer by playing music (machine using too much computing power)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "XF Android Button Rendering On Press is Malfunctioning" (#3303) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues -->

### Description

Creating a basic, customized pill button in Xamarin Forms where I supply a fade to color animation on the button's Pressed event results in a strange, mini version of the button appearing in the upper left corner of its layout on Android as well as its fill being darker than intended (see screenshots below). I tried to remedy by supplying a CustomRenderer that sets StateListAnimator to null and it made no difference. Also out of random desperation tried to enable the experimental fast renderers and that too of course did not help.

Please advise on a quick fix, or if this is indeed a bug that I must wait to get addressed. Thank you.

### Steps to Reproduce

My setup aside, here's the min steps to see this issue in action:
1.  Create new Xamarin Forms project targeting Android
2.  Add the following XAML to the main page:
```
    <ContentPage.Resources>
        <ResourceDictionary>
            <Style
                x:Key="PillButtonStyle"
                TargetType="{x:Type Button}">
                <Setter
                    Property="BackgroundColor"
                    Value="Transparent" />
                <Setter
                    Property="TextColor"
                    Value="LimeGreen" />
                <Setter
                    Property="BorderColor"
                    Value="LimeGreen" />
                <Setter
                    Property="BorderWidth"
                    Value="2" />
                <Setter
                    Property="CornerRadius"
                    Value="30" />
            </Style>
        </ResourceDictionary>
    </ContentPage.Resources>
    <StackLayout
        HorizontalOptions="CenterAndExpand"
        VerticalOptions="CenterAndExpand">
        <Button
            x:Name="btn"
            Style="{x:StaticResource PillButtonStyle}"
            Text="Test" />
    </StackLayout>
```
3. Add this to the code-behind:
`btn.Pressed += (sender, e) => { btn.BackgroundColor = Color.LightSeaGreen; };`

4. Run on device/emulator, and press down on the button for a couple of seconds to see that the mini button phenomenon occurs in the upper left of its layout. While still pressing, move your finger (or cursor in emulator :) ) off the button, it will show the proper visual state.

### Expected Behavior

No weird mini button fading in and out on press. And no "mask" distorting the fill color from what was set in the code.


### Basic Information

- Version with issue: 3.1.0.637273
- Last known good version: n/a
- IDE: VS2017 Enterprise 15.7.5
- Platform Target Frameworks: <!-- All that apply -->
  - Android: 8.1

- Android Support Library Version: v27.0.2.1
- Nuget Packages: Irrelevant
- Affected Devices: All Real and Emulated

### Screenshots

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13161978/42721336-ad74a484-876b-11e8-9b72-c152c9de1384.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "XF Android Button Rendering On Press is Malfunctioning" (#3303) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues -->

### Description

Creating a basic, customized pill button in Xamarin Forms where I supply a fade to color animation on the button's Pressed event results in a strange, mini version of the button appearing in the upper left corner of its layout on Android as well as its fill being darker than intended (see screenshots below). I tried to remedy by supplying a CustomRenderer that sets StateListAnimator to null and it made no difference. Also out of random desperation tried to enable the experimental fast renderers and that too of course did not help.

Please advise on a quick fix, or if this is indeed a bug that I must wait to get addressed. Thank you.

### Steps to Reproduce

My setup aside, here's the min steps to see this issue in action:
1.  Create new Xamarin Forms project targeting Android
2.  Add the following XAML to the main page:
```
    <ContentPage.Resources>
        <ResourceDictionary>
            <Style
                x:Key="PillButtonStyle"

                <Setter
                    Property="BackgroundColor"
                    Value="Transparent" />
                <Setter

                <Setter
                    Property="BorderWidth"

        HorizontalOptions="CenterAndExpand"
        VerticalOptions="CenterAndExpand">

```

4. Run on device/emulator, and press down on the button for a couple of seconds to see that the mini button phenomenon occurs in the upper left of its layout. While still pressing, move your finger (or cursor in emulator :) ) off the button, it will show the proper visual state.

Events.RelatedBody:

Please fill in the *entire* template below.
The template is designed to avoid unnecessary delays to confirm and fix reported issues. Issues with missing information generally end up with a `need-info` label and take significally more time to fix. Please help us help you!
For more information see https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-macios/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-&-Suggestions
For support requests use https://www.xamarin.com/support
-->
### Steps to Reproduce

1. apply patch https://gist.github.com/marek-safar/e564ad5efdbe66387ae53b17ddea86a6
2. make run-ios-sim64-linkall
3. 

### Expected Behavior

No crash

### Actual Behavior

```
2018-06-03 09:24:06.089 link all[65308:6402124] Xamarin.iOS: Internal consistency error, please file a bug (http://bugzilla.xamarin.com). Additional data: found managed object 0x126028ea8=0x7fb3f9052880 (Linker.Sealer.Unsealable) in native object 0x60c000223540 (AppDelegate).
2018-06-03 09:24:06.091 link all[65308:6402124] critical: Stacktrace:

2018-06-03 09:24:06.091 link all[65308:6402124] critical:   at <unknown> <0xffffffff>
